  • 0.6.3

For a general overview of how Ember Simple Auth works, see the README

SimpleAuth.Authenticators.Devise

Authenticator that works with the Ruby gem Devise.

As token authentication is not actually part of devise anymore, the server needs to implement some customizations to work with this authenticator - see the README and discussion here.

The factory for this authenticator is registered as 'simple-auth-authenticator:devise' in Ember's container.

Importing

ES6 modules
import Devise from 'simple-auth-devise/authenticators/devise';
Standard AMD
var Devise = requireModule('simple-auth-devise/authenticators/devise').default;

Properties

source

serverTokenEndpoint String

The endpoint on the server the authenticator acquires the auth token and email from.

This value can be configured via the global environment object:

window.ENV = window.ENV || {};
window.ENV['simple-auth-devise'] = {
  serverTokenEndpoint: '/some/other/endpoint'
}
Defaults to '/users/sign_in'
source

resourceName String

The devise resource name

This value can be configured via the global environment object:

window.ENV = window.ENV || {};
window.ENV['simple-auth-devise'] = {
  resourceName: 'account'
}
Defaults to 'user'

Methods

source

restore(properties) → Ember.RSVP.Promise

Restores the session from a set of session properties; will return a resolving promise when there's a non-empty user_token and a non-empty user_email in the properties and a rejecting promise otherwise.

Arguments

properties Object

The properties to restore the session from

Returns

→ Ember.RSVP.Promise

A promise that when it resolves results in the session being authenticated

source

authenticate(options) → Ember.RSVP.Promise

Authenticates the session with the specified credentials; the credentials are POSTed to the Authenticators.Devise#serverTokenEndpoint and if they are valid the server returns an auth token and email in response. If the credentials are valid and authentication succeeds, a promise that resolves with the server's response is returned, otherwise a promise that rejects with the server error is returned.

Arguments

options Object

The credentials to authenticate the session with

Returns

→ Ember.RSVP.Promise

A promise that resolves when an auth token and email is successfully acquired from the server and rejects otherwise

source

invalidate() → Ember.RSVP.Promise

Does nothing

Returns

→ Ember.RSVP.Promise

A resolving promise

Extends

Base

Properties

  • serverTokenEndpoint
  • resourceName

Methods

  • restore
  • authenticate
  • invalidate

SimpleAuth.Authorizers.Devise

Authenticator that works with the Ruby gem Devise by sending the user_token and user_email properties from the session in the Authorization header.

As token authentication is not actually part of devise anymore, the server needs to implement some customizations to work with this authenticator - see the README for more information.

The factory for this authorizer is registered as 'simple-auth-authorizer:devise' in Ember's container.

Importing

ES6 modules
import Devise from 'simple-auth-devise/authorizers/devise';
Standard AMD
var Devise = requireModule('simple-auth-devise/authorizers/devise').default;

Methods

source

authorize(jqXHR, requestOptions)

Authorizes an XHR request by sending the user_token and user_email properties from the session in the Authorization header:

Authorization: Token token="<user_token>", user_email="<user_email>"

Arguments

jqXHR JqXHR

The XHR request to authorize (see http://api.jquery.com/jQuery.ajax/#jqXHR)

requestOptions Object

The options as provided to the $.ajax method (see http://api.jquery.com/jQuery.ajaxPrefilter/)

Extends

Base

Methods

  • authorize
